material.mattext: Aaron Stampler deceives everyone; Rubin Carter is deceived BY the system. According to Vrij et al. (2019), what do these cases together suggest about institutional deception detection?
Legal systems are excellent at detecting individual deception
Institutions cannot be deceived
Neither individuals nor institutions reliably detect deception; the direction of deception (perpetrator vs. victim) does not predict detection accuracy
Only psychopaths can deceive institutions

Correct!

The two cases together illustrate that deception detection fails regardless of direction. Aaron (guilty) successfully deceives the system claiming innocence. The witnesses against Carter (lying) successfully deceive the system to convict an innocent man. Vrij et al.'s finding that detection accuracy is near chance applies to both scenarios. Institutions don't detect deception better than individuals, and being on the "right side" doesn't improve detection.

The correct answer is C.

The two cases together illustrate that deception detection fails regardless of direction. Aaron (guilty) successfully deceives the system claiming innocence. The witnesses against Carter (lying) successfully deceive the system to convict an innocent man. Vrij et al.'s finding that detection accuracy is near chance applies to both scenarios. Institutions don't detect deception better than individuals, and being on the "right side" doesn't improve detection.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Both films contradict this directly. Aaron fools the system; false witnesses fool the system against Carter.
  • B: The Carter case shows institutions CAN be deceived through false testimony.
  • D: Carter's accusers weren't psychopaths; they were ordinary people who lied successfully.

Martin Vail discovers he was manipulated after the verdict is final. Rubin Carter knew he was being manipulated but was powerless to stop it. According to research on belief perseverance (Boudry & Braeckman, 2012), why did both men initially fail to recognize the truth?
Intelligence does not protect against deception
Emotional investment prevented objective evaluation
Both operated within self-validating belief systems - Vail's about his client, Carter's accuser's about his guilt - that reinterpreted contradictory evidence to confirm existing beliefs
The legal system prevented truth-seeking

Correct!

Boudry & Braeckman's framework explains both cases. Vail's belief in Aaron's innocence became self-validating - Aaron's consistent performance reinforced the belief, and any inconsistencies were interpreted as trauma symptoms. Carter's accusers held self-validating beliefs about his guilt - his race, reputation, and presence near the scene confirmed their expectations. Both belief systems processed contradictory evidence as confirmation.

The correct answer is C.

  • A: True but doesn't explain the specific mechanism of belief maintenance.
  • B: Partially correct but doesn't capture the SELF-VALIDATING nature of the beliefs.
  • D: The system was used, but the psychological mechanism was belief perseverance.

Primal Fear depicts a guilty person escaping justice; The Hurricane depicts an innocent person denied justice. According to Diamond (1961) on criminal responsibility, what fundamental challenge does this contrast illustrate?
The insanity defense should be abolished
Mental illness always leads to injustice
The legal system must balance two types of errors - convicting the innocent and acquitting the guilty - and mental illness complicates both determinations
Criminal responsibility can be objectively determined

Correct!

Diamond's analysis of criminal responsibility acknowledges that legal systems must balance Type I errors (convicting innocents) against Type II errors (acquitting the guilty). Both films show these errors occurring: Aaron exploits mental illness claims to avoid accountability (Type II error); Carter is convicted despite innocence (Type I error). Mental illness complicates both because it's difficult to assess and can be feigned or ignored.

The correct answer is C.

  • A: This wouldn't solve either problem and isn't supported by the films.
  • B: Too absolute. Mental illness is one complicating factor among many.
  • D: Both films show that responsibility determination is subjective and error-prone.
Carter refused to wear prison clothes or participate in prison programs. According to McKnight & Kashdan (2009), how might this defiance relate to purpose maintenance?
Defiance indicates purpose rejection
Maintaining identity boundaries preserves the self-organizing system of purpose even when external circumstances are uncontrollable
Purpose cannot exist within incarceration
Defiance is always maladaptive

Correct!

McKnight & Kashdan describe purpose as a self-organizing system that maintains itself through consistent behavior aligned with core values. Carter's defiance maintains his identity as an innocent man, not a criminal. By refusing prison clothing and programs, he preserves the boundary between who he IS (innocent fighter) and what the system claims he is (convicted murderer). This boundary maintenance sustains his purpose even when he can't change his circumstances.

The correct answer is B.

Both films feature attorneys who believe their clients. What does Shermer's (2002) analysis of "smart people believing weird things" suggest about expert vulnerability to deception?
Legal training specifically protects against deception
Attorneys are randomly selected for gullibility
Expertise provides sophisticated tools for rationalizing conclusions reached through intuition and emotional investment
Smart people never believe false things

Correct!

Shermer's core insight is that intelligence and expertise provide better tools for RATIONALIZATION, not better truth-detection. Vail's legal expertise allowed him to construct sophisticated justifications for believing Aaron. Carter's attorneys had expertise that helped them build an innocence case. In both directions, expertise serves to support pre-existing conclusions rather than objectively evaluate them. Smart professionals use their skills to defend their beliefs.

The correct answer is C.

  • D: Directly contradicts Shermer's thesis.
